title: Catwoman
descriptions:
In Catwoman (2004), timid graphic designer Patience Phillips works for the powerful cosmetics conglomerate Hedare Beauty, run by icy CEO Laurel Hedare and her polished husband, George. Patience stumbles upon a dark corporate secret: their soon-to-launch anti-aging product, Beau-line, is dangerously toxic and can disfigure or addict users. When she overhears plans to release it anyway, security corners her in a wastewater tunnel and leaves her to drown.

A mysterious Egyptian Mau cat revives Patience, imbuing her with catlike agility, hypersenses, and a rebellious alter ego. Confused by her new instincts and driven by flashes of the night she died, she fashions a leather-clad persona—Catwoman—oscillating between liberation and vengeance. She begins tracking those responsible for her death, stealing clues and confronting the company’s enforcers, while her midnight exploits draw the attention of honest cop Tom Lone, who is romantically interested in Patience and suspicious of Catwoman’s crimes.

As Catwoman peels back the layers of the conspiracy, she learns Beau-line’s secret: long-term use renders skin nearly indestructible but at the cost of severe dependency and side effects. George, revealed as philandering and ruthless, becomes a prime suspect, but the true mastermind is Laurel, who has been using the product extensively and plans to market it regardless of the risks. Laurel frames Catwoman for George’s murder to eliminate both her husband and the vigilante threat.

Patience tries to maintain her relationship with Tom while shielding her identity, but he pieces together the truth. In a climactic showdown at Hedare’s skyscraper, Catwoman confronts Laurel. Laurel’s Beau-line-enhanced skin turns blows aside, but her face fractures when slammed into broken glass. Catwoman refuses to kill her; Laurel falls to her death after slipping during the struggle.

Cleared of the murder and having exposed the company’s deception, Patience rejects returning to her old life or rekindling things with Tom. Embracing her newfound independence, she walks away as Catwoman—a lone, feline antihero who prowls the night on her own terms, balanced between justice and freedom.
